captions.text:
In 1905, Albert Einstein published a series
of papers that many consider a starting point

for the modern age of physics. But other than
"E equals m c squared", most people only know

that Einstein was famous, not for what he
was famous. Since this week marks the 133rd

anniversary of his birth, as is customary
in western traditions we will celebrate by
taking a brief tour of his scientific publications.

Today, his paper from March, 1905 on why light
is a particle.

Einstein didn't just pull this idea out of
thin air – he first noted that the light

emitted from something hot (like a lightbulb
filament), actually has the same energy distribution

as a gas, which is somewhat surprising if
you're a nineteenth century physicist who

thinks that light is a continuous wave and
very much not a gas composed of individual

molecules. And while the idea that "light
behaves kind of like a gas" was already well

known before Einstein, no one had taken the
logical but crazy next step to conclude that

light must then be made of individual particles,
too! So Einstein proposed that these "light-quanta"

were in fact real particles that could account
for a few recent and unexplained experiments

having to do with knocking electrons off of
metals or gas molecules. He turned out to

be right on all counts and got a nobel prize
for his work… but that's a story for another

title: Albert Einstein: Why Light is Quantum

comments.text:
Today is not only Pi Day (3.14), but it is also the birthday of one of the 
greatest scientists of all time, Albert Einstein. 

He was born on this date in 1879. Einstein developed the theory of 
relativity (among many other things), which forever changed Physics! He 
received the Nobel Prize in 1921. 

This video from MinutePhysics available within +YouTube education explains 
4 of his most important pieces of work.

Albert Einstein: Why Light is Quantum﻿

comments.text:
Poincaré attributed the development of the new mechanics almost entirely to 
Lorentz.  Lorentz said this in 1927:

*"I considered my time transformation only as a heuristic working 
hypothesis. So the theory of relativity is really solely Einstein's work. 
And there can be no doubt that he would have conceived it even if the work 
of all his predecessors in the theory of this field had not been done at 
all. His work is in this respect independent of the previous theories."*

Sorry Einstein haters, but he was a genius.

comments.text:
Relativity was first conceptualised by Galileo, which is why it's known as 
Galileo's Principle of Relativity. What Einstein did was solve the apparent 
contradiction between the Principle of Relativity and Maxwell's Theory of 
Electromagnetism.

comments.text:
+Nick Hastings  Looping.  Meaning something near an atom [like light] can 
be traveling straight but to outside observers it appears it is moving in a 
circle or "torus shell" space.  Caused by amplifying, crossing, standing 
waves of energy that change the shape of space and rate of time near the 
atom.  i.e the reason atoms don't fly apart like atomic bombs.
   What Einstein missed.  If he knew that e=mcc should actually be e=mc/Tr 
then he didn't say.  Einstein originally thought Minkowski [Einstein's old 
teacher] was just doing tricks with math.  Look up Minkowski space on 
wikipedia.  Minkowski basically tied together Poincare, Maxwell, Lorentz 
and Einstein works by adding what they could not see which is the 
understanding that time is part of space and when size of space changes 
then so does the rate of time. Which is why E=mc^2 should not be e=mcc but 
e=mc/[time rate].  Time rate of anything moving at c is near zero, like an 
inversion of 300,000,000m/s is .00000000033 s/m [ie very slow time].  So 
that it shows what space-time is and that mass is concentrated energy for a 
reason since there can be nothing that moves faster than c or slower than 
zero time rate per frame.  Duh!  Since Einstein missed this that also means 
[and I can tell] that he didn't make the connection that gravity is a form 
of light and travels at light speed and that all energy [not just the 
gravity energy] is responsible for changing the concentration of 
space-time.  Modern science barely has a clue.  Science went way off track 
in the 1930s - 40s once the atomic bomb and quest for understanding 
particles "quantum" occured.  What they do not see now, if they ever did, 
is that symetry and vibrations of EMF energy [light] is particle as 
concentrated light and some harmonics are what hold atoms together.  
Nuclear fission is the injection of a "neutron"  what's a neutron?  It's an 
"alpha particle" bounced off the core of another atom.  It is very short 
lived when outside an atom [decays] because there is not enough symmetry 
[energy density enough to maintain space-time warp symmetry around it] 
holding together the space-time of that energy.  Why does it cause 
fission?...I may need to think on that more...not coming to me...must be 
that neutrons carry a larger space and faster time contained by a decaying 
symmetry shell so that it partially breaks the harmonics of high density 
atoms like uranium and plutonium.  Thanks for the question. Helped me 
understand what I hadn't before.

awareness without being sucked into confusion by genius want-to-be that

If you invert and divide with one of the c of the equivalence  e=mcc then

comments.text:
The word QUANTUM has been around since the 1840's.

Einstein popularized the idiom 'quanta' in his 1905 paper explaining 
wave-particle duality because he had to describe the particle nature of 
light.  He described 'particle light' as localized (in a space) radiation 
that he named 'lightquanta'.

The term has many more meaning's in many different fields because it's 
definition is starkly simple.  Wiki's referenced definition is:
"The minimum amount of any physical entity involved in an interaction"

You're confusion Quantum with Quantum MECHANIC's ... a new field of physics 
(at the time) that relied on quanta of energy in the sub-atomic particles 
in the standard model (6 quarks (up, down, charm, strange, top, bottom), 6 
anti-quarks, 6 leptons (electron, tau, muon and their respective 
neutrino's), 6 anti-leptons, and of course the 4 force carrier particles 
called bosons (photon's carry the EM force, 'gravitons'* carry the force of 
gravity, gluons impart the strong nuclear force and W-/W+/Z0 carry the weak 
nuclear force) .... AND the final piece of the puzzle ... the HIGGS BOSON, 
the force carrier that impart's mass on matter)..

He worked with quantum physics because he had to.  His objections were 
metaphysical.  He couldn't accept that EVERYTHING is random like many of 
the principles of quantum theories requires but he also couldn't deny that 
these quantum theories explained things that were otherwise unexplainable 
exceptionally well.  He did many quantum physics maths during his life.

*We have never observed a 'graviton', and since gravity is so many order's 
of magnitude WEAKER then the other 3 forces it's not believed we'll have 
the beam energy (in particle collider's) to generate enough graviton's that 
they're existence can be statistically confirmed.  I don't know exactly how 
much but gravity is billions or trillions of times weaker then the other 3 
forces.  People mistakenly think it's a strong force ... and in fact they 
think it's the strongest force, but it's because gravity permeates all of 
spacetime whereas EM, Strong nuclear and weak nuclear are localized in 
space.
comments.author: MDMA4LIFE

comments.text:
Great question. Water-wave medium is water. Sound-wave medium is air. EMF 
spectrum-waves (light) is on a medium. The medium is not nearly so tangibly 
observable as with other waves. There is very little evidence (light 
lensing around galaxies, etc.) and even less understanding (dark 
matter/energy) of what I describe as a medium. The medium is 
rate-of-time-differences (space-time). Lack of this understanding has 
bottle necked some physics for the last 70 years or so.
comments.author: thinkrealify

comments.text:
This is an invitation to see an artist model of the physics of ‘time’ as a 
physical process. In this theory the physics of quantum mechanics 
represents the physics of ‘time’ as a physical process. The spontaneous 
absorption and emission of light (wave particle duality) is forming a blank 
canvas that we can interact with turning the possible into the actual! Time 
is an emergent property with the future coming into existence photon by 
photon relative to the actions of the atoms.
comments.author: An artist theory on the physics of 'Time' as a physical process. Quantum Atom Theory

comments.text:
Why do you think light is a particle? The way I see it there is no 
particles of any type unless you consider differences in rate-of-time to be 
"particles". So yeah. I can see why Einstein would say photons are 
particles where Bohr did not; because you can (depending on your definition 
of the term) look at it different ways. Waves on water, sound waves, radio 
waves, light waves, etc, etc. Wave is a motion in a "particle" medium but 
not the source and not the medium. Light medium =space-time

Two reasons I do not think light is a particle. 1. (Light speed is the 
fastest wave propagation speed that the slowest time rate can be in a 
regional gravity density) so that if light were a particle that had mass it 
would take much more than a flash light to propel it to the speed barrier 
as described in GTR (published 11 years later). 2. Light, like all waves, 
is energy introduced into a medium (rate of time).

Ah, well that's just a manifestation of our the energy output of our star.

Coincidentally, IR makes up about 40% of the suns energy and many animals 
on earth have adapted IR sensors to observe the world around them.

comments.text:
sorry, I forgot to add that atoms, because they are much larger wouldn't be 
absorbed as readily as photons, and photons naturally travel extremely fast 
so they don't dissipate in quite the same way as gas (they hit and absorb 
or reflect, much less 'bouncy' than gaseous atoms or molecules) but 
otherwise they are very similar.
comments.author: Brent Cromwell

comments.text:
Because the photons were absorbed by the parts of your mouth that were 
illuminated by the light, thus they would never make it into your lungs 
which remain dark. It's a difference in energy, gas particles are floating 
arrangements of subatomic particles, ie; electrons, protons and neutrons, 
however light is a single particle so it is readily absorbed by the larger 
atoms as energy. When compared to a gas, light particles or photons 
"spread" out in very similar way. That's all he's sayin :)
comments.author: Brent Cromwell
